newsitem.title: IRAQ: Iraq to send helicopters into West's no-fly zone.
newsitem.headline: Iraq to send helicopters into West's no-fly zone.

text.p: Iraq has decided to send helicopters to pick up Iraqi Moslem pilgrims from the Saudi border in the south despite a U.S. and allied ban on flights by Iraq in the area, the Iraqi News Agency reported on Monday.
It said the decision was announced after a meeting of Iraqi leaders headed by President Saddam Hussein in which they warned the United States against any attempt to intercept the helicopters.
"Any American practice threatening the safety of the helicopters and the pilgrims will be met with an appropriate action," the news agency INA said, quoting an authoritative source.
Iraq flew a civilian plane to Saudi Arabia on March 9 carrying 104 elderly and sick pilgrims to Mecca for the haj pilgrimage despite U.N. sanctions. The plane returned home the same day.
The U.N. Security Council issued a statement calling on Iraq not to fly more planes without its consent, but stopped short of regarding the flight as a breach of the embargo.
INA said "practical reasons" prevented Iraq from sending the plane back to transfer the pilgrims home.
